(This Document is the Property of His Britannic""Ma 3 e sty^s^Gove rrauengT)" '---*-.-SE0RET-OABINHT 8 (25).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet,held at 10, Downing- Street, S.W.1, onTHURSDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1925, at 11 a.m.NAVY ESTI-MATES.(previous reference:Cabinet 7(25), Con-conclusion 21.)THE proposed conference ONLIMITATIONOP naval armaments.previous reference:Cabinet 7(25), oon-conclusion 20.lo The Cabinet resumed the discussion of the navy estimates, whioh had been begun on the previous day.The Prime Minister summed up the general viewof the Cabinet in the following terms:.-"Tho Cabinet has decided that the processof replacing the units of the Fleet whichare becoming obsolete through age shouldbe dealt with by a programme extendingever a period of years." For this purposean Inquiry will be Instituted forthwithby the Cabinet into the requirements oftho Fleet in cruisers and other vessels not now within the scope of the WashingtonAgreement, and the age standards of replacement which should be adopted. pThis Inquiry must necessarily occupytwo or three months. His Majesty1 sGovernment have also expressed their willingness to take part in a new naval conference at Washington with a view tothe further limiting" of naval armaments and expenditure. The results of such aConference would, of course, have animportant bearing upon the recommendationof the Committeeof Inquiry and thedecision of the Cabinet thereupon. It isnet proposed to authorise any new programmeof construction at this stage. Such a pro-gramme will be formulated later in the year,and Supplementary Estimates will be intro-duced for whatever may prove to be requiredfor the current year. 11 1 ,.252The Cabinet agreed (a) That the Prime Minister, the Chancellorof the Exchequer, and suoh other colleagues as the Prime Minister might desire, should meet the First Lord and First Sea Lord,and, on the basis of the above statement,should seek to arrive at precise conclusions in regard to outstanding questions, includ-ing the total amount of "the sum to bopresented to Parliament for the navy estimates 1925-26, Vote "A" and othermatters,"(b) That the Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs, in consultation with the FirstLord of the' Admiralty, should prepare for the consideration of the cabinet a draft despatch to the British ambassador in Washington, in which he should instruct the Ambassador to repeat formally to theAmerican Secretary of State the welcomewhich Mr Chamberlain had already givento the American Ambassador of the Ideaof a new Naval Conference at Washingtonwith a view to the further limiting ofnaval armaments and expenditure. 2 5 3ijHS ARMY 2. The Cabinet approved the t-ernie-of1 the draftS0PPLEME KTARYRESERVE. letter from the Army Council to Mr Cramp, the- Industrial General Secretary, National Union of railwaymen, on the subject of the Army SupplementaryReserve, attached to the Memorandum by the Secretaryof State for War (Paper CP. -66 (25)).2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.l,February 12, 1925.
